text:
I've made a pull request that should give you a working emulator that fails with Mu images. If you can get Mu running in this environment, I'll do a little more work to make the web presentation nice.
<https://github.com/akkartik/mu/pull/49>

attachments.title: Add v86 example, currently not working by jackrusher 路 Pull Request #49 路 akkartik/mu
attachments.text: This adds a browser subdirectory with everything needed to boot an emulated Pentium with SeaBIOS and a VGA BIOS that tries to load a bootable hard drive image from the file code.img in the same dir...
attachments.fallback: GitHub: Add v86 example, currently not working by jackrusher 路 Pull Request #49 路 akkartik/mu

text: One more guess: it's not the .js files here that are incompatible with Mu but the .bin BIOS ROMs. Maybe video memory is mapped to a different place. I'll check it!

elements.text: One more guess: it's not the .js files here that are incompatible with Mu but the .bin BIOS ROMs. Maybe video memory is mapped to a different place. I'll check it!

text: SeaBIOS is also used by qemu, so I think it must be okay. OTOH, the VGA bios used by v86 is not the same as qemu (which uses the one from Bochs). I'll try the Bochs one now.

elements.text: SeaBIOS is also used by qemu, so I think it must be okay. OTOH, the VGA bios used by v86 is not the same as qemu (which uses the one from Bochs). I'll try the Bochs one now.

text: Switching out the Bochs versions of both BIOS bins has the benefit of being much slower, which allowed me to watch the emulator boot up with a band of blue at the top and then overwrite the band with green dots until it hit to #NP exception.

I can reproduce it, thank you!

The fact that the screen looks different leads me to wonder if the two configurations are failing in different ways. Still, the bochs failure is easier to debug so I'll search where the light is.

text:
Ooh, this state from Mar 15 works:

```git checkout bc182ae559580d4d2cde6d5c5e8ed3bb5906bdb5
./translate_subx boot.subx ex2.subx          # emits disk.img```

elements.text: Ooh, this state from Mar 15 works:

git checkout bc182ae559580d4d2cde6d5c5e8ed3bb5906bdb5
./translate_subx boot.subx ex2.subx          # emits disk.img

text: I would assume a problem with v86 on the basis that Mu works fine with qemu, but so many other images work fine that I'm suspicious of a corner case in Mu's output. If I have some time tomorrow, I might do some more testing myself with a minimal bootable thing. v86 strikes me as a nice tool for pedagogy, probably in the context of an online essay about programming at this layer.

elements.text: I would assume a problem with v86 on the basis that Mu works fine with qemu, but so many other images work fine that I'm suspicious of a corner case in Mu's output. text: Aha! You're on the trail! :smile:

elements.text: Aha! You're on the trail!

text: The major new feature since then is the ATA disk driver.

elements.text: The major new feature since then is the ATA disk driver.

text: I'm gonna take off as well for the day. Thank you so much!

elements.text: I'm gonna take off as well for the day. Thank you so much!

text: The disk driver was a red herring. The Bochs BIOS mostly works! There's just some boot-up unit test(s) failing that are hard to spot because of the initial screen corruption. If I disable tests all the programs work! Including the whole programming environment. About 5s per screen repaint/keypress, so _really_ slow.

elements.text: The disk driver was a red herring. The Bochs BIOS mostly works! There's just some boot-up unit test(s) failing that are hard to spot because of the initial screen corruption. If I disable tests all the programs work! Including the whole programming environment. About 5s per screen repaint/keypress, so
really
slow.

text:
Looks like there's something lacking in the way I initialize the floating point unit. Turning mu-init.subx into this fails to print '0' and logs the `#NP` exception to the console:
```== code

Entry:
  f3 0f 58/add %xmm2 0x00000000/x32  # add xmm2 to xmm0   <=== deleting this line prints '0' and throws no exception
  (draw-grapheme-on-real-screen 0x30 0 0 7 0)
  # hang indefinitely
  {
    eb/jump loop/disp8
  }```
(Run this with just `./translate`; no .mu arg required.)

Here's how I initialize the FPU right now in boot.subx. I definitely recall cutting corners, though I don't recall what they were.
```  ## enable floating point
  db/floating-point-coprocessor e3/initialize
  # eax <- cr4
  0f 20/<-cr 3/mod/direct 0/rm32/eax 4/r32/cr4
  # eax <- or bit 9
  0f ba/bit-test 5/subop/bit-test-and-set 3/mod/direct 0/rm32/eax 9/imm8
  # cr4 <- eax
  0f 22/->cr 3/mod/direct 0/rm32/eax 4/r32/cr4```

elements.text: Looks like there's something lacking in the way I initialize the floating point unit. Turning mu-init.subx into this fails to print '0' and logs the
#NP
exception to the console:

== code

Entry:
  f3 0f 58/add %xmm2 0x00000000/x32  # add xmm2 to xmm0   <=== deleting this line prints '0' and throws no exception
  (draw-grapheme-on-real-screen 0x30 0 0 7 0)
  # hang indefinitely
  {
    eb/jump loop/disp8
  }
(Run this with just
./translate

; no .mu arg required.)

Here's how I initialize the FPU right now in boot.subx. I definitely recall cutting corners, though I don't recall what they were.

## enable floating point
  db/floating-point-coprocessor e3/initialize
  # eax <- cr4
  0f 20/<-cr 3/mod/direct 0/rm32/eax 4/r32/cr4
  # eax <- or bit 9
  0f ba/bit-test 5/subop/bit-test-and-set 3/mod/direct 0/rm32/eax 9/imm8
  # cr4 <- eax
  0f 22/->cr 3/mod/direct 0/rm32/eax 4/r32/cr4
